Hyun Ryu † Yunwoo Nam † Hyun S. Ahn * Department of Chemistry, Yonsei University, 50 Yonsei-ro, Seodaemun-gu, Seoul 03722, Korea Department of Chemistry Yonsei University 50 Yonsei-ro, Seodaemun-gu Seoul 03722 Korea Department of Chemistry, Yonsei University, 50 Yonsei-ro, Seodaemun-gu, Seoul 03722, Korea * Corresponding author † Contributed equally to this work ABSTRACT Development of reaction-tailored electrocatalysts is becoming increasingly important as energy and environment are among key issues governing our sustainable future. Electrocatalysts are inherently optimized for application towards reactions of interest in renewable energy, such as those involved in water splitting and artificial photosynthesis, owing to its energy efficiency, simple fabrication, and ease of operation. In this view, it is important to secure logical design principles for the synthesis of electrocatalysts for various reactions of interest, and also understand their catalytic mechanisms in the respective reactions for improvements in further iterations. In this review, we introduce several key methods of scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) in its applications towards electrocatalysis. A brief history and a handful of seminal works in the SECM field is introduced in advancing the synthetic designs of electrocatalysts and elucidation of the operating mechanism. New developments in nano-sizing of the electrodes in attempts for improved spatial resolution of SECM is also introduced, and the application of nanoelectrodes towards the investigation of formerly inaccessible single catalytic entities is shared. Graphical Abstract Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) is a powerful for the interrogation of surface phenomena on electrocatalysts. In this review, we introduce significant examples in the literature that paved the foundation for electroanalytical examination of the electrocatalytic processes by SECM and discuss their implications in rational synthetic designs for electrocatalyts and detailed study of the reaction mechanism. Keywords Scanning electrochemical microscopy Electrocatalysis Surface reaction Electroanalytical chemistry In situ electrochemical analysis Direct quantification 1 Introduction Scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) was first introduced by Fan et al. [1] in 1989. SECM has been employed to study electrochemical and morphological properties of heterogeneous and homogeneous reactions of various substrates with high resolution. The applications of SECM have been developed and applied to various analytes, such as electrocatalysts, photocatalysts, nanoparticles, and battery surfaces. Also, many operation modes of SECM recently evolved with the advent of nanotechnology to achieve more meticulous analysis. 1.1 Components A scanning electrochemical microscope consists of four electrodes (tip electrode, counter electrode, reference electrode, and substrate electrode) and is mounted on a three-dimensional positioning system. The resolution of an SECM is determined by the size of the tip electrode and the spatial resolution of the positioner moving the tip. Typical modern commercial SECMs can reach nanometer-level resolutions owing to the development in the fabrication of nanoelectrodes [2–5]. 1.2 Operation modes Since the introduction of SECM (Fig. 1 ), various operation modes [6] were developed, each with unique application in mind. Among them, the most basic methods are feedback modes and generation/collection (G-C) modes. Many advanced methodologies were stemmed from the two modes, and in this section we will introduce the governing principles underlying the operations of feedback and G-C modes, along with the surface-interrogation mode that is the most relevant for advanced analysis of the surfaces of electrocatalysts. 1.2.1 Feedback mode The feedback mode is the most fundamental mode of SECM operation. The tip current (iT ) at a certain time is determined by how fast the reactants arrive at the electrode surface. If the radius of the tip electrode approaches the length of the diffusion layer (as with a UME), the diffusive flux of the reactant to the electrode increases by means of spherical diffusion, and the diffusion-limited steady state current (i ss) is observed. For a disk-type UME, i ss is given by Eq. (1). (1) i ∞ = 4nFDCa where n is the number of electrons participating in the reaction, F is the Faraday’s constant (96485 C/mol), D is the diffusion coefficient of the redox molecule (cm2/s), C is the redox mediator concentration (mol/cm3), and a is the radius of the tip (m). When the tip approaches the substrate, iT is influenced by the combination of (1) redox molecule regeneration by the reverse reaction at the substrate (positive feedback; Figs. 2(b) )) and (2) hindrance of redox molecule diffusion by the approaching substrate (negative feedback; Fig. 2(a))). Interference in the redox mediator diffusion to the tip electrode decreases the current and the redox mediator regeneration at the substrate increases the current. Positive and negative feedback typically occurs on conducting and insulating substrates, respectively. Current-distance relationships from feedback mode data is typically plotted and modeled in the form of normalized current (iT/i∞) vs. normalized distance L (d/a) (Fig. 2(d))) [7–10]. Also, the effect of the ratio of the radius of the glass sheath to that of the electrode (RG) can affect the shape of the feedback curve, therefore RG is an important parameter in model fitting the obtained data [10]. 1.2.2 Generation-collection modes Generation-collection mode of SECM takes advantage of redox relay between the tip and the substrate electrodes that are within feedback distance. There are two types of generation-collection modes (Fig. 3 ). In the tip generation and substrate collection mode (TG/SC), the redox reaction O + ne- → R occurs at tip and the reactant is collected at the substrate by the reverse reaction (in this example the oxidation of R to O). Homogeneous chemical reaction rates were studied using TG/SC mode, where longer the distance between tip and substrate electrodes, the more time is allowed for R to undergo a chemical reaction, therefore lower substrate collection current is recorded. Substrate generation and the tip collection mode (SG/TC) is the opposite of TG/SC. The SG/TC mode is meaningful in that it allows a user to study the local environments of a relatively large electrode. Substrate electrodes are typically much larger than the paired tip electrode, therefore SG/TC mode enables the probe of localized generation rate of a substance, ultimately leading to mapping of local reactivity or electron transfer capability of the substrate by the tip. 1.2.3 Surface interrogation SECM Analysis of surface adsorbed chemical species, whether it be adsorbed forms of reactants, products, or intermediates, is of paramount importance in understanding heterogeneous catalysis. Electrocatalysis is inherently heterogeneous, by involvement of electrodes, and therefore characterization of adsorbate on catalysts electrodes is valuable in assessing electrocatalysis [11,12]. In addition to the mapping of local reactivities and quantification of steady-state electron transfer coefficients by implementation of feedback and G-C modes (vide supra), a transient mode of SECM can be applied to electrocatalysts in order to obtain valuable kinetic information regarding surface-adsorbed intermediates [13]. This mode is termed surface interrogation SECM (SI-SECM), during which the substrate electrode is composed of the electrocatalysts under investigation, and the tip serves as the probe for the 'interrogation’ of the substrate surface via electrochemical titration. During electrocatalysis of the substrate, the tip can produce reactive redox mediator species that can microtitrate the adsorbed species on the surface of the electrocatalysts. By implementing various different redox species, the chemical potential of the surface species under investigation can be pinned, their surface coverage quantified, and by control of the time space of the titration reaction the kinematic rate information can be described. In this review, we cover SECM applications to electrocatalysis, centered on the three operating modes described above. 2 Analyses of electrocatalysts by SECM 2.1 SECM studies of electrocatalysts Since Bard and coworkers first presented the possibility of scanning electrochemical microscopy as a catalyst analysis tool in 1990, SECM has been widely applied in electrocatalyst research [14]. A number of unique feature of SECM are desirable in its application to electrocatalysts analysis: (1) in-situ study of electrocatalysts is possible in the native environment and in the presence of solvent and electrolyte [15], (2) simultaneous analysis of morphology and chemical reactivity can be achieved, rendering a correlation map of structure-reactivity to avail, and (3) by using a small-sized electrode, spatial resolution in the nanometer range can be obtained. Aside from analyzing surface catalysis and providing chemical information pertinent to the reaction mechanism, SECM also finds its use in rapid scans of catalyst arrays of various compositions for combinatorial screening for optimal stoichiometries and elemental compositions for catalyst design. Currently, SECM applications to single-entity (single nanoparticle, terraces, grain boundaries, etc) analysis is actively pursued. 2.2 Catalyst array screening When designing multi-component catalysts, process of finding the ideal ratio of the components is usually tedious and time consuming. By employing SECM, this obstacle can be solved simply through catalyst array screening. Modified SECM can be optimized for preparing arrays of small spots of different compositions and also screening the arrays rapidly to find the best performing composition. First, SECM can move precisely at regular intervals. Piezo-electric dispenser combined with accurate movement control travels a certain distance and drops a calculated amount of metal salt solution, which becomes a catalyst spot of a unique composition. Repeated spot generation in regular intervals and variation in the ratio of mix component result in an array of catalysts surveyed. A large number of different compositions can be screened rapidly. Catalyst spot arrays of different compositions can be analyzed by adopting various modes of SECM—feedback or generation/collection—according to the purpose of analysis. Through this process, an appropriate ratio of components for various reactions—hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [16,17], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [18,19], carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) [20], formic acid oxidation reaction (FAOR) [21]—were investigated. In 2005, Fernández et al. [19] proposed guidelines for the design of improved multi-metallic electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in acidic media. Piezo-electric dispenser, which is computer-controlled to locate and dispense at precise position, delivered pL-drops of metal salt solution to form array spots. (Fig. 4(a) )). After one metal salt was deposited, the solution is drained from the dispenser and solution of another metal salt was dropped over the same array. The result was an array of drops containing different calculated amounts of each metal salt. The researchers showed that the array has formed successfully by scanning electron micrographs (SEM) of typical arrays of catalyst spots consisting of various amounts of Pd, Co and Au (Figs. 4(b)), (c)). Optimized ratio of metals for improved ORR activity was revealed by wide, fast SECM scanning (Figs. 4(d)), (e)). 2.3 Single entity analysis Since Talyor [23] proposed that catalytic reaction only occurs at specific active sites on the solid catalyst in 1925, research on discovering and utilizing catalyst active sites is prevalent in the study of heterogeneous catalysis. Most research of this type is focused on macroscopic structure modification [24–26], which increases the number of active sites, or on microscopic environment engineering which increases the local activity of active sites [27–29]. Nowadays, it is accepted that all surface sites are not uniform, and therefore in the case of electrocatalysts, current distribution on a given catalyst surface is uneven. Therefore, studies analyzing average activity of entire bulk system are insufficient to fully analyze the unique characteristics of a collection of catalyst active sites [30]. Naturally, importance of research that analyze intrinsic activity of single catalytic sites is rising (Fig. 5 ). Especially, recently developed nanoelectrodes have enabled the understanding of intrinsic activity of surface sites with high spatial resolution [31,32]. The application of nanoelectrodes to single entity (e.g., a single cell, a single nanoparticle) activity analysis has yielded unprecedented, valuable results [33,34]. 2.3.1 Single nanoparticles Analyses of single nanoparticles are the most common examples of SECM studies on single catalytic entities. It is essential to analyze how each of the variables affects the catalytic reaction from a single particle perspective [35]. In 2014, HER activity of single Au nanoparticle and its tafel slope was obtained [36]. Mirkin et al. [37] also introduced the tunnelling mode of SECM to probe electrochemical reaction at single Au nanoparticles. Size, surface, composition, and shape of metal nanoparticles strongly affects their catalytic activities. Shape dependence of nanoparticle catalytic properties (e.g., electron transfer rate constants, catalytic rate constants) has been reported through many studies in recent years [39,40]. For example, platinum nanoparticles with different shapes—spherical, cubic, hexagonal, and tetrahedral-octahedral—were compared for their activity as oxygen reduction reaction catalyst by SECM (Fig. 6 ) [38]. Different activity according to shape was revealed by SECM scanning across particle arrays. Furthermore, the researchers suggested that difference in catalytic activity according to the morphology could be analyzed in-situ by SECM. Development of nanoelectrodes facilitated single nanoparticle analysis in SECM research. In 2016, Kim et al. [41] reported the analysis of a single platinum nanoparticle and its electron transfer reaction with SECM (Fig. 7 ). Platinum nanoparticles on highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) were observed individually. Outer-sphere electron transfer agent (FcTMA+) was used to obtain topographical data, and inner-sphere mediator (H+) was employed to obtain surface catalytic activity and the reaction rate constant. This work revealed structure-activity relationship of metal nanoparticles at high resolution, and suggested guideline for similar studies to design optimal catalysts for various reactions. By employing an extremely small electrode, it has become possible to distinguish specific active sites on the surface of a nanoparticle beyond analyzing the characteristics of a single nanoparticle. Surface structure and reaction active site distribution of single Au nanoparticles were studied by SECCM, employing a 30 nm single-channeled nanopipette (Fig. 8 ) [42]. Electro-oxidation of [N2H5]+ at the surface of electrodeposited Au nanoparticles was investigated. 2.3.2 Local site activity SECM studies on low-dimensional nanomaterials are actively being conducted, as the interest in these materials as electrocatalysts increased. Especially, analyzing catalytic characteristics of two-dimensional surface defects (step edges, corner, facets) is necessary, as local atomic structure at these sites lead to distinct local catalytic activity. Unwin et al. [43] electrochemically mapped molybdenite (MoS2), 2D semiconductor material in order to reveal the difference in HER characteristics of basal and edge plane of planar structure using scanning electrochemical cell microscopy (SECCM). Sun et al. [44] analyzed the catalytic activity difference of the step edge and basal plane of semi-2D nickel oxide nanosheet by employing two types of redox reaction – outer-sphere reaction (Fc/Fc+) to achieve topographic data of NiO nanosheet and inner-sphere reaction (OER) to measure catalytic activity of local site. Using nanoelectrodes, feedback mode was employed to achieve topographic data of NiO structure. After the surface structure was revealed by feedback mode, SG/TC mode via OER enabled in-situ analysis of NiO as an oxygen evolution catalyst. The study confirmed that the edge sites of nanosheets shows higher catalytic activity compared to that of the adjacent basal plane. Understanding structure-activity relationship of electrocatalyst is a fundamental step in designing an optimal catalyst. Grain boundary (GB), interface between two grains, is a structural motif of interest in polycrystalline materials. In electrocatalysis, enhanced catalytic activity on grain boundary is often reported. Electrochemical and crystallographic surface analysis using SECCM and electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) were performed concurrently to characterize the relationship between local active site density and corresponding electrochemical activity. Fig. 10 shows grain boundary analysis of Fe2+ oxidation reaction on a polycrystalline platinum electrode [45]. The result showed that the electrochemical activity was different for dissimilar grains, and some grain boundaries show higher activity compared to the adjacent grains. The study confirmed that local structure imposes different properties even if the chemical composition is the same. In addition, this result supported the hypothesis that control of the growth and density of grain and grain boundaries are important to catalyst design. [46] observed enhanced reduction currents at grain boundary on a polycrystalline Au surface by SECCM and EBSD. Following this study, Unwin and Kanan et al. [47] visualized reduction current in CO2 saturated atmosphere which enhanced at grain boundary of Au electrode for higher resolution. The researchers found that the sites where dislocations are dense, such as GB, are more important for the overall catalytic reaction than lattice strain. A series of works, including several of the forementioned examples, have widely acknowledged surface site nonuniformity and necessitated active site analysis at the single entity level. However, as the size of these active sites is typically small (in the order of nanometers), making individual analysis difficult. Investigations by modern SECM enhanced by nanoelectrodes have shown that these obstacles can be overcome while retaining the advantages of in-situ analysis. 3 Reaction kinetics analysis 3.1 Homogeneous reaction kinetics estimation via approach curve Approach curve and surface interrogation methods are the most representative types of analytical means for assessing electron transfer kinetics. The current-distance relationship in an approach curve depends on the rate of homogeneous reaction of reagent in solution and the heterogenous reaction rate at the substrate. For example, in ECi processes, a commonly observed reaction mechanism, the following processes occur: Tip (Generation): O + ne– → R E Re Q M = E FF ( system ) - E FF ( inner ) + E QM ( inner ) Substrate (Collection): R – ne– → O The amount of R collected at the substrate will be a function of the distance between the tip-substrate, because the tip-substrate gap will determine the residence time of R in solution. The chemical reaction of R in solution will be the competing reaction to the electrochemical collection of R at the substrate, and therefore by model-fitting the the approach curve (distance-current relationship), the homogeneous reaction rate constant k can be obtained. The model-fitting process is typically done on a Multiphysics software, such as COMSOL. Studies based on the approach curve and simulation fitting proposed the rate constant of dimerization of CO2 radicals (Fig. 11(a) )) [49] and N,N-dimethylaniline (DMA) radicals (Fig. 11(b))) [48]. Other reaction kinetic studies and applications are given in Table 1 . 3.2 Heterogeneous reaction kinetics analysis via surface interrogation SECM Inspection of catalytic intermediates in-situ is desirable, but analytical methods that meet the demands for such detection (time resolution comparable to the lifetime of chemical species of interest, detection in the presence of electrolyte, quantitative analysis, etc) are rare. A new SECM methods for characterization of surface intermediates was introduced by Rodríguez-Lo?pez et al. [13] recently. This mode, surface interrogation SECM (SI-SECM), selectively and quantitatively analyzes surface intermediates that evolve during catalysis. By taking advantage of the transient state in between positive and negative feedbacks, the SI-SECM allows the user to quantify surface adsorbed chemical species, often reaction intermediates, without probing the bulk. 3.2.1 Experimental procedures and conditions The quantification mechanism of SI-SECM is based on the principle that the activated redox mediator reacts with the intermediates at the surface. The feedback current from the surface is used to quantify the amount of adsorbates on the unbiased substrate after activation. In SI-SECM, the tip is concentrically placed above the substrate and approached close (at least L = d/a ≤ 0.3) for obtaining complete collection of the feedback at the tip. The substrate size should be comparable or smaller than that of tip for quantitative detection of the feedback current. In an SI-SECM process, the electrocatalyst on the substrate is initially pulsed or scanned to a range of activation for sufficient formation of intermediates of interest on the catalytic surface (Fig. 12(a) )). In the next step, the substrate rests at open circuit potential and the redox mediators, activated at the tip, react with the adsorbed species which was formed during the first step (Fig. 12(b))). The tip current is integrated to measure the amount of the intermediates (Fig. 12(c))). As shown in Fig. 12(d)), the response of the SI-SECM is placed between the positive and the negative feedback currents. There are few conditions required of the redox mediator for SI-SECM application, such as stability, solubility, and potential difference large enough to ensure facile reaction with the adsorbates on the surface [66]. 3.2.2 Digital simulation of the SI-SECM process Flexible simulation softwares such as COMSOL Multiphysics and Mathematica have been adapted to simulate SI-SECM datasets. The electrode surface, the insulating domain, and the electrolyte are typically simplified as depicted in Fig. 13 . Typical simulations assume Fick’s law of diffusion in solution, as in Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) ∂Co/∂t = DO▽2 C O (2) ∂CR/∂t = DR▽2 C R C O: Concentration of oxidized species C R: Concentration of reduced species DO: Diffusion coefficient of oxidized species DR: Diffusion coefficient of reduced species At the electrode surface, Butler-Volmer kinetics is typically adopted. The consideration of adsorbed species (A) on catalyst is the unique adjustment made for SI-SECM calculations. In Fig. 13(a)), the second order interrogation reaction is occurred at the substrate surface with kinetic constant k and described by Eq. (3). Eqs. (4‒6) describes the concentration change of redox species and adsorbates with time at the substrate electrode. (3) R + A → k 0 (4) ∂Co/∂t = kC R C A (5) ∂CR/∂t = ‒kC R C A (6) ∂CA/∂t = DA▽2 C A ‒ kC R C A C A: Concentration of adsorbates DA: Diffusion coefficient of adsorbates From the model the adsorbate surface concentration can be simulated, and the experimental data can be fit, from which the kinetic rate constant k can be estimated (Fig. 13(b))). 3.2.3 SI-SECM reaction intermediate quantification and elucidation of electrocatalytic mechanisms Since the introduction of SI-SECM in 2008, many catalysts were investigated by its implementation. Early SI-SECM researches proposed analysis of stable adsorbates: hydrogen on platinum and gold, oxides of platinum and gold, and adsorbed carbon monoxide on platinum [13,66–68]. In order interrogate highly reactive surface intermediates during electrocatalysis, improved time resolution of SI-SECM was required. The bottleneck in the time domain was the time required for mechanical switching action between the catalyst activation (Fig. 12(a))) and interrogation (Fig. 12(b))). Switches in commercial SECMs experience at least 50 µs time loss in data collection due to mechanical throws between the two electrodes of the bipotentiostat. Therefore, Ahn et al. [69] applied an additional digital device, externally located, for the meticulous time control. In this work, time resolution was improved to 1 µs, allowing the researchers the control of the time space comparable to the lifetimes of fast reacting intermediates in reactions of interest, such as ORR, OER, HER, and CO2RR. Fig. 14(b) ) shows the significant difference of the charge density, obtained by SI-SECM, before and after the implementation of the external switching device. Oxygen evolution is a key reaction in energy conversion, and many catalyst candidates are actively under investigation. Oxides of iridium [70–81], cobalt [82–88], and nickel [89–95] are commonly studied. Iridium oxide garnered abundant interests due to its unique stability in acid. Arroyo-Curra?s et al. [96] divulged multiple oxidation states of iridium before OER onset (Fig. 15(a) )). Especially, monolayer coverages of adsorbed hydroxide for each oxidation states of iridium were quantified. The charge density of monolayer of adsorbed hydroxide (456 μC/cm2) was 100 μC/cm2 lower than the previously reported value [97], showing that surface species investigation capability of SI-SECM is superior to the conventional methods employing a single electrode. Another widely studied OER catalyst, the CoP i , was studied by Ahn et al. [98]. In this study, precise charge density of each cobalt oxidation states (Co(III) and Co(IV)) was revealed by the usage of two redox mediators with distinct redox potentials. Kinetic rate constants of CoPi OER reaction were quantified via time-dependent titration of SI-SECM, and the exact OER turnover frequency (TOF) of cobalt atoms was evaluated. Several follow-up studies have been made on cobalt electrocatalysis using SI-SECM [69,99]. Similarly, various manganese oxidation states were selectively evaluated by Bard and coworkers [100]. A more recent application of SI-SECM towards OER electrocatalysts expanded its utility by differentiating between more than one type of catalytically active sites in a mixed metal oxide material. Nickel iron oxides have been heavily studied for OER [101–110] since the late 1980s [111]. In a recent work, various ratios of nickel-iron mixed oxides were studied by Ahn et al. [112] (Fig. 16(a) )), in their communication it was revealed that isolated iron sites in a continued matrix of NiOOH is the active species responsible for rapid OER (Fig. 16(c))). The HER is the fuel-forming reaction in water splitting. The main hurdle in HER is the development of materials to substitute platinum, the benchmark catalyst. MoS2 [113–122] and nickel are representative materials studied as Pt replacement candidates. Inaugural works on SI-SECM application of HER catalysts revealed surface intermediate lifetimes, their coverage, and reaction mechanism details of nickel and MoS2 (Figs. 17 and 18 ) [123,124]. Application of SI-SECM was recently extended to CO2RR (Fig. 19(a) )) [125], where the competing HER and competitive adsorption of -CO and -H were investigated for the elucidation of the mechanistic details of the reaction pathways leading to the product of interest, the C-C coupled fuels [126]. 4 Conclusions In this review, we shared the operating principles of several key methods of SECM, and their applications toward better understanding electrocatalysts. Most electrocatalysts concerned in this review are pertinent to renewable energy, centered around reactions such as OER, ORR, HER, and CO2RR. A number if seminal works were critically reviewed, in the electrocatalysts fields for (1) combinatorial designs of electrocatalysts stoichiometries for optimized product selectivity and (2) elucidation of the reaction mechanism and time-dependent quantification of reaction intermediate concentration. The SECM community has contributed significantly in developing electroanalytical means to tackle problems in electro- and heterogeneous catalysis. Especially with recent development of nanoelectrodes and subsequent improvement in the SECM spatial resolution, we believe SECM will be even more of a formidable tool in the comprehensive understanding of electrocatalysts for important reactions in the storage, conversion, and utilization of renewable energy sources. coredata.dc:description: ABSTRACT Development of reaction-tailored electrocatalysts is becoming increasingly important as energy and environment are among key issues governing our sustainable future. Electrocatalysts are inherently optimized for application towards reactions of interest in renewable energy, such as those involved in water splitting and artificial photosynthesis, owing to its energy efficiency, simple fabrication, and ease of operation. In this view, it is important to secure logical design principles for the synthesis of electrocatalysts for various reactions of interest, and also understand their catalytic mechanisms in the respective reactions for improvements in further iterations. In this review, we introduce several key methods of scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) in its applications towards electrocatalysis. A brief history and a handful of seminal works in the SECM field is introduced in advancing the synthetic designs of electrocatalysts and elucidation of the operating mechanism. New developments in nano-sizing of the electrodes in attempts for improved spatial resolution of SECM is also introduced, and the application of nanoelectrodes towards the investigation of formerly inaccessible single catalytic entities is shared.

coredata.dc:title: Modern applications of scanning electrochemical microscopy in the analysis of electrocatalytic surface reactions
